parse.title: List of U.S. state and territory nicknames

text.*:
Map of the United States showing the state nicknames as hogs. Lithograph by Mackwitz, St. Louis, 1884.

The following is a table of U.S. state and territory nicknames, including officially adopted nicknames, and other traditional nicknames for individual states and territories of the United States (and the District of Columbia).

Contents

  • 1 State and territory nicknames
  • 2 See also
  • 3 Notes
  • 4 References
  • 5 External links

State and territory nicknames[edit]

Current official state and territory nicknames are highlighted in bold. A state nickname is not to be confused with an official state motto.

State Nickname(s)
 Alabama
[1][A]
  • Cotton Plantation State[2]
  • Cotton State[3]
  • Heart of Dixie (used on license plates)[3][4][5]
  • Lizard State[2]
  • Yellowhammer State[3]
 Alaska
  • Land of the Midnight Sun[6]
  • Land of the Noonday Moon[6]
  • The Last Frontier (currently used on license plates)[6][7]
  • Seward's Folly (named after U.S. Secretary of State William H. Seward)[6]
  • Seward's Ice Box, Icebergia, Polaria, Walrussia, and Johnson's Polar Bear Garden were satirical names coined by members of the U.S. Congress during debate over the Alaska Purchase[6]
 American Samoa
  • Motu o Fiafiaga (a Samoan phrase; in English, it is "Islands of Paradise")[8] (currently used on American Samoa license plates)[9]
  • Football Island[s][10]
 Arizona
  • Apache State[11]
  • Aztec State[11]
  • Baby State (Because Arizona is the newest contiguous state in the Union)[11]
  • Copper State[11]
  • Grand Canyon State (currently used on license plates)[11][12]
  • Italy of America[11]
  • Sand Hill State[11]
  • Sunset State[11]
  • Sweetheart State (See below)[11]
  • Valentine State (Arizona gained statehood on February 14, 1912)[11]
 Arkansas
  • Bear State[13]
  • Bowie State[13]
  • Hot Springs State[13]
  • Land of Opportunity (former official nickname; previously used on license plates)[13]
  • The Natural State (currently used on license plates)[13][14]
  • Razorback State[13]
  • Toothpick State[13]
  • Wonder State[13]
 California
  • El Dorado State[15]
  • The Golden State[16][17] (previously used on license plates)
 Colorado
  • Buffalo Plains State[18] (no longer used)
  • Centennial State[19] (previously used on license plates. Colorado was admitted to the Union one hundred years after the signing of the Declaration of Independence.)
  • Colorful Colorado[19] (previously used on license plates)
  • Columbine State[20]
  • Highest State[18]
  • Lead State[18] (no longer used)
  • Mother of Rivers[21]
  • Rocky Mountain Empire[22] (no longer used)
  • Rocky Mountain State[23] (no longer used)
  • Silver State[18] (no longer used; see Nevada)
  • Ski Country USA[24]
  • Switzerland of America[25][26]
 Connecticut
  • Constitution State (official, currently used on license plates)[27]
  • Nutmeg State[15]
  • Provision State[28]
  • Blue Law State[15]
  • Freestone State[15]
  • Land of Steady Habits[15]
 Delaware
  • Chemical Capital of the World[29] (due to one time being the corporate headquarters for several international chemical companies.)
  • Corporate Capital (due to the state's business-friendly incorporation laws)[29]
  • Diamond State (Thomas Jefferson is supposed to have referred to Delaware as being like a diamond- small in size but great in value)[30]
  • Blue Hen State or Blue Hen Chicken State[31]
  • The First State[29][32] (Delaware was the first state to ratify the Constitution; currently used on license plates)
  • Peach State[29] (no longer used; see Georgia)
  • Small Wonder[29]
 District of Columbia[A]
  • Nation's Capital[33]
  • DMV (nickname for the broader metropolitan area of Washington, D.C., Maryland, and Virginia)[33]
  • Inside the Beltway
 Florida
  • Alligator State[34]
  • Everglade State[34]
  • Flower State[34]
  • Gulf State[34]
  • Orange State[34]
  • Peninsula State or Peninsular State[31]
  • Sunshine State (currently used on license plates)
 Georgia
  • Peach State[35] (currently used on license plates)
  • Cracker State — Along with Florida, Georgia had been called "The Cracker State" in earlier times, perhaps a derogatory term that referred to immigrants, called "crackers," from the mountains of Virginia and North Carolina.[36] See also Atlanta Crackers: Origin of the name
  • Empire State of the South — Georgia is the largest state in land area east of the Mississippi and was the leading industrial state of the Old South.[37]
  • Goober State — Refers to peanuts, the official state crop.[38]
  • State of Adventure (On highway welcome signs)
 Guam
  • Tano y Chamorro (Land of the Chamorro)[39] (currently used on Guam license plates)[40][41]
  • Hub of the Pacific
  • Gateway to Micronesia
 Hawaii
  • Aloha State (officially the "popular" name,[42] currently used on license plates)[43]
  • Paradise of the Pacific[43]
  • Pineapple State[43]
  • Rainbow State[44]
  • Youngest State[43]
  • 808 State (colloquial, refers to the state's area code.)[45][46]
 Idaho
  • Gem State[47]
  • Gem of the Mountains[48]
  • Little Ida[48]
  • Spud State[49]
 Illinois[50]
  • Land of Lincoln[51] (currently used on license plates)
  • Prairie State[51]
  • Corn State[51]
  • Garden of the West[51]
 Indiana
  • Hoosier State[52]
 Iowa
  • Hawkeye State[53]
 Kansas
  • America's Heartland (previously used on Licence Plates)
  • Central State[15]
  • Dorothy's Home
  • Midway USA (previously used on Kansas Licence Plates)
  • Sunflower State[15]
  • Wheat State (previously used on license plates)
 Kentucky
  • Bluegrass State (currently used on license plates)[54]
  • Corn-cracker State (reported in 1881)[31]
  • The Dark and Bloody Ground State (an allusion to battles between the Creek, Shawnee, Chickasaw, and Cherokee tribes)[54]
  • Hemp State[54]
  • Tobacco State[54]
 Louisiana
  • Bayou State (previously used on license plates)
  • Creole State[15]
  • Pelican State[15]
  • Sportsman's Paradise (currently used on license plates)
 Maine
  • Vacationland (currently used on license plates)
  • Pine Tree State[55] (Co-official with Vacationland)
  • Lumber State[15]
 Maryland
  • America in Miniature[56]
  • Chesapeake State[57]
  • Cockade State[57]
  • Free State[58]
  • Monumental State[57]
  • Old Line State[57]
  • Oyster State[57]
  • Queen State[57]
  • Terrapin State[59]
 Massachusetts
  • Baked Bean State[60]
  • Codfish State (formerly represented on license plates by a codfish)
  • The Bay State[60]
  • Old Colony State[61]
  • Pilgrim State[60]
  • The Spirit of America (currently used on license plates)
  • The People's Republic of Massachusetts (colloquial)
  • Taxachusetts (colloquial)[62][63][64][65][66]
 Michigan
  • The Great Lakes State (previously used on license plates)
  • Water Wonderland and Water-Winter Wonderland (previously used on license plates)
  • The Wolverine State[67]
  • The Mitten State
 Minnesota
  • Gopher State[15]
  • Land of 10,000 Lakes ("10,000 Lakes" currently used on license plates)
  • New England of the West[15]
  • North Star State
  • State of Hockey[68]
  • ”Minne(snow)ta”
  • Bread and Butter State[15]
 Mississippi
  • Hospitality State (previously used on license plates)
  • Magnolia State
  • The Birthplace of America's Music (currently being used on license plates)
  • The Bayou State[15]
 Missouri
  • Bullion State[15]
  • Show-Me State (currently used on license plates)
 Montana
  • Big Sky Country (previously used on license plates)
  • The Last Best Place[69]
  • Treasure State (currently used on license plates)
 Nebraska
  • Antelope State[70]
  • Beef State (previously used on license plates)
  • Cornhusker State (previously used on license plates)[71][70]
  • Bugeating State[72][70]
  • Blackwater State[15][70]
  • The Good Life (as seen on state border signs)
  • Tree Planters State[70]
 Nevada
  • Battle Born State (refers to the fact that Nevada joined the Union during the Civil War)
  • Sagebrush State
  • Silver State (currently used on license plates)
 New Hampshire
  • Granite State[73]
  • The Live Free or Die State (official motto; "Live Free or Die" currently used on license plates)
  • Mother of Rivers[73]
  • White Mountain State[73]
 New Jersey
  • Garden State (currently used on license plates)
  • The Crossroads of the Revolution (previously used on license plates)
  • Garbage State (derogatory reference, punned off "Garden State")[74]
 New Mexico
  • Cactus State[75][not in citation given]
  • Land of Enchantment[76] (currently used on license plates)
  • Land of Sunshine (predates "Land of Enchantment"; this earlier nickname highlighted the large percentage of sunshine received statewide)[75]
 New York
  • Empire State (currently used on license plates)[15]
  • Excelsior State[15]
 North Carolina
  • Old North State[77]
  • Tar Heel State[77]
  • Turpentine State[78]
  • Variety Vacationland[79]
  • First in Flight State (currently used on license plates)
  • First in Freedom (currently used on license plates)
  North Dakota
  • Flickertail State
  • Peace Garden State (currently used on license plates)
  • Rough Rider State
  • Sioux State
 Northern Mariana Islands
  • Håfa Adai (a Chamorro phrase; in English, it is "Hello")[80] (currently used on Northern Mariana Islands license plates)[81]
  • America's Best Kept Secret[82]
 Ohio
  • Buckeye State[31]
  • Birthplace of Aviation[83] (currently used on license plates)
  • The Heart Of It All[84] (formerly used on license plates)
 Oklahoma
  • Native America (currently used on license plates)
  • Sooner State[85]
 Oregon
  • Beaver State[86]
  • Pacific Wonderland (previously used on license plates and currently available on an extra cost plate)[87]
  • Webfoot State[15]
 Pennsylvania
  • Keystone State (previously used on license plates)[31]
  • Quaker State
 Puerto Rico
  • Isla del Encanto ("Island of Enchantment") (currently used on license plates)
  • Borinquen (name given by indigenous people, the Tainos)[88]
  • The Other Area 51
  • Progress Island[89]
 Rhode Island
  • Little Rhody[31]
  • Ocean State (currently used on license plates)
  • Rogues Island[90]
  • The Licentious Republic[90]
 South Carolina
  • Palmetto State[31]
  • Iodine Products State (no longer used)[91] (previously used on license plates)
 South Dakota
  • Artesian State[92]
  • Blizzard State[92]
  • Coyote State[92]
  • Land of Infinite Variety
  • The Mount Rushmore State[93] (officially adopted in 1980 in place of the former nickname of Coyote State)[92]
  • Sunshine State[92] (no longer used; see Florida)
 Tennessee
  • Big Bend State (refers to the Tennessee River)[94]
  • Butternut State (refers to the tan color of the uniforms worn by Tennessee soldiers in the American Civil War)[94]
  • Hog and Hominy State[94]
  • The Mother of Southwestern Statesmen[94]
  • Volunteer State[94] (currently used on license plates)
 Texas
  • Lone Star State[31][95] (currently used on license plates)
  • Friendship State
 U.S. Virgin Islands[A]
  • America's Caribbean (used on U.S. Virgin Islands license plates until 2015)[96]
  • American Paradise[97]
 Utah
  • Beehive State
  • Mormon State[98]
  • Friendly State (formerly used on license plates)[99]
 Vermont
  • Green Mountain State[31] (currently used on license plates)
 Virginia
  • Mother of Presidents[15]
  • Mother of States[15]
  • Horse Country[15]
  • The Old Dominion[31]
 Washington
  • Evergreen State[100] (currently used on license plates)
 West Virginia
  • Mountain State (previously used on license plates)
  • Panhandle State[15]
 Wisconsin
[101][A]
  • Badger State[15]
  • America's Dairyland[102][103] (Also on license plates since a 1939 state law)[101]
  • The Mitten State
  • The Copper State (historical)[104][105]
  • The Dairy State
 Wyoming
  • Cowboy State
  • Equality State
  • Forever West (on highway welcome signs)

See also[edit]

  • Lists portal
  • List of U.S. state mottos
  • List of demonyms for U.S. states
  • List of city nicknames in the United States
  • List of provincial and territorial nicknames in Canada
  • Lists of nicknames – nickname list articles on Wikipedia

Notes[edit]

A. ^ No official nickname
